data.title: Flex LNG signals $340M-$360M revenue guidance for 2025 amid strong backlog
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: FLEX LNG Ltd. (NYSE:FLNG) Q4 2024

Management View

  • CEO Oystein Kalleklev highlighted that revenues for Q4 2024 were $90.9M, which included $1.4M from EU ETS-related compensation, aligning with earlier guidance. Adjusted net income for the quarter was $30.8M, with adjusted earnings per share at $0.57.
  • Recent strategic milestones included the extension of charters for Flex Resolute and Flex Courageous to 2032, with options through 2039, and a 15-year charter for Flex Constellation starting Q1/Q2 2026, securing significant long-term revenue.
  • The company completed refinancing efforts, raising $430M, releasing $97M in cash, and extending debt maturities while reducing interest costs.
  • CFO Knut Traaholt confirmed that Q4 adjusted EBITDA aligned with guidance at $271M-$274M, and technical fleet uptime reached 99.7%, reflecting high operational efficiency.

Outlook

  • FLEX LNG projects 2025 revenues to be in the range of $340M-$360M, supported by stable backlog and anticipated time charter equivalent earnings in the mid-$70,000s per day.
  • EBITDA for 2025 is expected to remain steady at $250M-$270M, continuing trends from 2024.
  • Four ships are scheduled for special surveys in 2025, which may impact operations temporarily.
  • Management reiterated its commitment to maintaining the quarterly dividend of $0.75 per share, amounting to $3 annually, backed by strong cash reserves of $437M and robust backlog coverage.

Financial Results

  • Q4 2024 revenues reached $90.9M, aligning with expectations. Net freight income stood at $89.5M, reflecting EU ETS-related adjustments.
  • Adjusted net income for Q4 2024 was $30.8M, with EPS of $0.84 and adjusted EPS of $0.57.
  • The company’s cash position remained strong at $437M, bolstered by refinancing activities and disciplined operational cost management.
  • Time charter equivalent earnings for both Q4 and the full year were consistent at approximately $75,000 per day.
  • Operating expenses were slightly below budget for Q4, demonstrating cost control despite higher crew change costs in Asia.

Q&A

  • Clare Pennington, ICIS: Asked about steam tankers' scrapping potential and operational costs. CEO Kalleklev explained that high operational costs of $15,000 per day make steam tankers economically unviable, prompting expected scrapping trends.
  • Analyst, ABN AMRO: Questioned the impact of MEGI and X-DF technologies. CEO Kalleklev emphasized MEGI engines' superior efficiency and reduced methane slip, which align better with emerging environmental regulations, despite higher initial costs.
  • Analyst: Inquired about Flex Constellation's strategy. CEO Kalleklev stated that the ship might trade in the spot market temporarily until tighter market conditions improve term charter opportunities.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts appeared neutral to slightly positive, with questions focusing on environmental compliance, fleet utilization, and dividend sustainability.
  • Management maintained a confident tone during prepared remarks but acknowledged short-term market challenges during the Q&A.
  • Compared to Q3, management’s tone remained steady, reflecting confidence in long-term contracts and backlog stability.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Q4 revenues of $90.9M were consistent with guidance, slightly higher than Q3’s $90.5M.
  • Adjusted EPS in Q4 was $0.57, a slight increase from Q3’s $0.53.
  • The outlook for 2025 revenue and EBITDA remains steady compared to 2024, though Q4 marked the first instance of quarterly figures dipping below Q3 due to soft freight rates.
  • Management sentiment remained stable, with confidence in long-term fundamentals despite acknowledging short-term market softness.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management flagged soft freight rates as a near-term challenge, with Q4 rates at unprecedented lows of $10,000 per day for older tonnage.
  • Upcoming special surveys for four ships in 2025 may temporarily impact fleet availability.
  • Regulatory costs associated with EU ETS and FuelEU Maritime were highlighted as ongoing challenges, although FLEX LNG benefits from a modern, efficient fleet.
  • Analyst questions indicated concerns about potential geopolitical risks, including U.S.-China trade tensions and their impact on LNG demand.

Final Takeaway

FLEX LNG Ltd. demonstrated resilience in Q4 2024 with revenues of $90.9M and steady operational performance despite soft freight markets. The company’s long-term backlog, robust cash position, and dividend stability indicate confidence in navigating near-term challenges. Guidance for 2025 projects revenue between $340M-$360M and EBITDA at $250M-$270M, supported by a modern fleet and strategic charter extensions. Key risks include short-term freight rate pressure and regulatory costs, but management remains optimistic about market recovery in 2027-2028, driven by fleet adjustments and LNG demand growth.

data.title: Tariffs would reduce North America's GDP – Fitch economists break it down
data.description:
President Trump’s current trade policy and its turn to protectionism is creating significant risk to macroeconomic forecasts, rising hits to GDP and weighing on global growth, according to an article by Fitch Ratings.

If implemented, tariffs on almost all imports from countries affected, would see a much bigger increase in effective U.S. tariff rates: from almost 0% to 25% for Mexico, and 20.5% for Canada.

Also, although a 10 percentage point increase in the effective U.S. tariff rate on Chinese imports to 20% “would less aggressive than the 25 percentage point rise assumed in [Fitch’s Global Economic Outlook report] but does not signal more generous treatment, in our view,” according to economists, headed by Brian Coulton.

They said that U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports will likely rise further this year, as President Trump has announced.

“The jump in effective tariff rates on Canada and Mexico incorporated in the Feb. 1 announcement, along with our GEO (Global Economic Outlook) tariff assumptions for U.S. imports from other countries, would result in the overall U.S. effective tariff rate rising from 2.3% in 2023 to 13.3%.”

“That compares to the December GEO assumption that the U.S. average effective tariff rate would rise to 7.9% and would have a much bigger impact on the U.S. economy than in the GEO scenario.”

Coulton explained that the 11 percentage point rise in the overall U.S. effective tariff rate equal an extra $350B in import taxes, compared to the 2023 tax assumption of $72B.

This is about 1.7% of U.S. consumption, and would put upward pressure on consumer prices and companies’ input costs, leading to an additional -0.4 percentage point impact on U.S. real GDP in 2026, double what was previously expected in Fitch’s GEO.

However, impacts on the Mexican and Canadian economics would be far bigger, the report said.

“Modelling the new tariff rates in the GEM (Fitch’s Global Sovereigns Outlook 2025 report) shows a negative real GDP impact in Mexico in 2026 of 2.3 percentage points from the GEO baseline, and of 1.4 percentage points for Canada.”

data.title: Boeing is said to see ‘significant’ gains in fixing quality issues
data.description:
Boeing (NYSE:BA) is seeing improvement in quality and fewer shortages in its supply chain as the aviation giant follows through on measures started last year, Bloomberg News reported Tuesday, citing a Boeing (NYSE:BA) executive.

The company is still on track to increase production of its best-selling 737 to more than a rate of 38 planes a month by mid-2025, Ihssane Mounir, a senior vice president who oversees Boeing’s (NYSE:BA) global supply chain, said the Pacific Northwest Aerospace Alliance conference near Seattle.

The comments about output goals echoed those by Boeing (BA) Chief Executive Kelly Ortberg on the company’s earnings call last month.

The improvements in quality include parts from key supplier Spirit AeroSystems Holdings (NYSE:SPR), which makes most of the air frame for the 737 Max.

Boeing (BA) last year focused on improving the quality and safety of its planes in response to a crisis in early 2024. A metal panel blew out from a 737 Max carrying 177 passengers and crew shortly after take-off, forcing an emergency landing.

The company and the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration are keeping an eye on six measures of work at Boeing’s (BA) factories and supply chain, and using the information to set the pace of output.

Mounir said the company also embedded “armies” of quality inspectors, engineers and other workers at suppliers throughout the world. It took a similar approach with Spirit (NYSE:SPR) and experienced success with it.

data.title: Archer Daniels Midland hit with Sell rating at CFRA after Q4 miss, layoffs
data.description:
Archer Daniels Midland (NYSE:ADM) -3% in Tuesday's trading after earlier falling more than 5% to its lowest in four years, as it reported Q4 earnings that fell 9% Y/Y to $667M with a cautious outlook for 2025, and said it would cut up to 700 jobs to reduce expenses.

Q4 revenues fell to $21.5B from $22.98B in the year-earlier quarter, and missed the $22.77B analyst consensus estimate, and operating profit in the agricultural services and oilseeds division, ADM's (NYSE:ADM) largest segment, fell by a third from a year ago on weak North American oilseed crushing margins and uncertainty around biofuel policies.

ADM (ADM), which has warned that a challenging commodities cycle would continue this year, said it is now focused on controlling costs to weather the downturn, and that it aims to cut costs by $500M-$750M over the next 3-5 years through job cuts and lower raw materials and manufacturing costs.

For FY 2025, ADM (ADM) forecast adjusted earnings of $4.00-$4.75/share, with the midpoint of guidance well below EPS of $4.74 in 2024 as well as the $4.66 analyst consensus estimate.

data.title: Fed’s hawkish lean and the AI tech jolt are shifting the bull-market narrative: Morgan Stanley
data.description:
Morgan Stanley Wealth Management (MSWM) is seeing a stall in the S&P 500 (SP500), and said the Federal Reserve halting its run of rate cuts is contributing to a change in the bull-market narrative.

The S&P 500 (SP500) is showing signs of fatigue after climbing ~70% since the bull market took off in 2022, and MSWM said beyond technicals, it’s seeing two fundamentals emerging. One is the Federal Reserve standing pat on interest rates after a run of rate cuts. The second is the prospect of low-cost AI innovation by Chinese startup DeepSeek that spurred last week’s selloff in tech stocks including Nvidia (NVDA).

Put together, MSWM said watch for rotation of stock index leadership from the Magnificent 7 stocks toward value, cyclicals and non-GenAI secular growth.

“Although January’s rate-cut pause was telegraphed, many still hoped the Fed would express confidence in accommodation. It did not, and investors now need to admit that policy-driven multiples expansion is near its limit, with the driver changing to earnings realization,” MSWM's Chief Investment Officer Lisa Shalett, said in a weekly report.

Meanwhile, the bull-market narrative has centered on momentum being sustained by U.S. tech innovation and “Magnificent Seven” AI dominance alongside falling interest rates that guide a soft economic landing sustaining momentum, Shalett said.

“Last week’s events … strengthened our view that the narrative is shifting and we are entering the 'Great Normalization,' she said. “We assert that it will be dominated by rate and valuation normalization; renewed focus on earnings growth as the driver of equities,” and deconcentration in the S&P 500 (SP500), she said.

As investor consensus on terminal rates circles around 3.75%-4.0%, so does the upper limit on expansion of multiples, Shalett said. That’s because the level of interest rates and negative equity risk premiums for market-cap leaders “must be acknowledged,” she said.

For investors interested in tracking the S&P 500 (SP500) through ETFs, here are a few: (SPY), (SH), (VOO), (RSP), and (IVV).

data.title: Federal Reserve in 'good position' to 'wait and see,' Daly says
data.description:
Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said Tuesday that the U.S. central bank, which last paused its rate-cutting cycle, can take its time to assess how economic data has evolved relative to its dual mandate of stable prices and full employment.

Assessing the current economic backdrop, Daly said there's "a lot of momentum" behind the U.S. economy, though inflation remains her biggest focus as it still hovers above the Fed's 2% target.

"We haven't finished the job" in containing inflation, Daly said in a panel hosted by the Commonwealth Club World Affairs of California.

Earlier on Tuesday, Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic said "inflation in housing costs is a major factor in inflation writ large."

data.title: 'Undervalued gas giant' Expand Energy initiated as Strong Buy at Raymond James
data.description:
Expand Energy (NASDAQ:EXE) +1.2% in Tuesday's trading as Raymond James launches coverage with a Strong Buy rating and a $135 price target, saying the company has ample room to grow and inventory to last decades into the future.

Expand (NASDAQ:EXE), which became the largest U.S. gas producer with the combination of Chesapeake Energy and Southwestern Energy, is poised for capital efficient growth given its significant spending in DUCs and deferred turn in-lines during a depressed price environment in recent years, Raymond James analyst John Freeman writes.

The investment in building the DUCs and deferred TILs provides Expand (EXE) with "the flexibility to push on the growth accelerator whenever they desire," and the company's extensive portfolio provides multiple decades of viable inventory and peer-leading growth in free cash flow, according to John Freeman.

Expand (EXE) has a backlog of ~80 deferred TILs and ~60 DUCs, which will allow it to quickly expand production north of 7B cfe/day in 2025, Freeman says; using Raymond James' gas price forecast of $4.00 in 2025 and $4.50 in 2026, he calculates the company's free cash flow yield will trail only Antero Resources (AR) in 2026 among gassy peers.

data.title: Omega Healthcare Q4 earnings stand to gain from investments, macro backdrop
data.description:
Omega Healthcare Investors (NYSE:OHI) is expected to benefit from the investments made by the skilled nursing facility provider as well as the macroeconomic backdrop.

OHI is scheduled to announce Q4 earnings results on Wednesday, February 5th, after market close.

The consensus FFO estimate is $0.72 (+6.35% Y/Y) and the consensus revenue estimate is $226.22M (+10.89% Y/Y).

Omega Healthcare posted Q3 earnings that exceeded consensus, as it continued to invest.

"We have accretively invested approximately $834M year-to-date and the pipeline continues to be strong. As a result, we are again increasing our 2024 AFFO guidance," CEO Taylor Pickett had said in the Q3 results announcement.

OHI completed $440M in new investments during the third quarter, consisting of $390M in real estate acquisitions and $50M in real estate loans. It completed $119M in new investments Q4-to-date as of October 30.

"As per NAREIT, OHI sees $600M+ of investments in 2025 as likely versus Street/BMOe at $515M/$750M (per Visible Alpha). In discussions with investors, we believe the 2025 bogey is closer to $1B. OHI also noted greater interest to deploy capital in U.S. fee simple structures. Going forward, OHI expects to capture a larger share of the industry investment pipeline following the PACS fallout," a report by BMO Capital Markets said.

"We look to gage OHI's views on potential Medicare or Medicaid cuts being discussed by Republicans to help pay for targeted initiatives as part of the budget reconciliation process. In addition, we look for the latest thoughts on more restrictive immigration policies and the impact to costs and rent coverage," the report noted.

"The healthcare sector is poised to increasingly benefit from the aging demographics in the U.S. Those born at the peak of the baby boom are now roughly 65 years old, entering retirement age when they will increasingly require different housing solutions and greater medical care," Truist Securities had said in a recent research note.

"Aging demographics are expected to meaningfully drive demand for skilled nursing facilities, and current supply trends appear insufficient to keep up. Despite high absolute costs, SNFs still remain a relatively cheaper environment for post-acute care," said Truist.

"Tenant issues appear to be largely behind OHI. The one issue to watch with SNF-focused operators is on the labor side. If lower income wages pick up, we note this could offset some of the benefit of the aging of America on SNF performance," BoA Securities said in its Q3 earnings recap.

The investment bank raised its 2024 AFFO estimate for the healthcare REIT to $2.72 from $2.68. The consensus stands at $2.82 (+0.94% Y/Y).

What to Expect

"The healthcare REITs in our coverage universe generally have low positive correlations to GDP, the broader stock market and REIT index over the past 10 years on an absolute and relative basis. Interestingly, the stocks in our healthcare REIT coverage universe have a very low correlation with the 10-year Treasury as well," said Truist analysts.

"Skilled nursing and senior housing performed significantly better than the other healthcare REITs we cover and the broader market, posting a 56%+ average total return (in our coverage)," said the note.

"The fundamental backdrop continues to improve as the healthcare industry has materially recovered from pandemic impacts and demand from aging demographics outpaces supply growth," said Truist.

"OHI could outperform on faster than expected leasing at Maplewood's (private) Inspir community in NYC or outsized external growth versus peers," Truist said with a Hold rating, citing the stock appears fairly valued.

The stock has risen 33.87% in the last one year.

The sell-side analysts and Seeking Alpha authors grade OHI as Buy. The Quant Rating system rates it as a Strong Buy.

data.title: Beyond rallies 26% after a well-received business update dials up the heat on shorts
data.description:
Beyond (NYSE:BYON) soared on Tuesday in a delayed reaction by investors to the company's announcement that it has entered into an asset purchase agreement with BBBY Acquisition to acquire the global rights of the Buy Buy Baby brand.

The purchase price of $5M includes certain assets, databases, domains, intellectual property, vendor relationships, and content related to Buy Buy Baby.

Beyond and tZERO, with its SEC-regulated special purpose broker dealer license, are also exploring the tokenization of a portion of the Buy Buy Baby intellectual property.

Jefferies analyst Jonathan Matuszewski and his team think the $5M price tag looks attractive for a brand that peaked with multiple billion in omnichannel revenue, especially considering Dream On Me paid $15.5M just 20 months ago. "That said, the brand has generated only ~$35M in TTM online revenue and will now operate under its 3rd different mgmt team in less than 2 years," warned Matuszewski.

On the financial front, Buy Buy Baby is expected to have a positive contribution to Beyond's (NYSE:BYON) 2025 margins.

Shares of Beyond (BYON) were up 25.6% in afternoon trading on Tuesday. Short interest stands at 19.2% of the total float, which may be adding to the volatility,

data.title: Everest Group targets 9% operating ROE for 2024 amid portfolio shifts and casualty discipline
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Everest Group (NYSE:EG) Q4 2024

Management View

  • CEO Jim Williamson highlighted a pre-tax net loss estimate of $350 million to $450 million from the California wildfires, primarily affecting the reinsurance division. He emphasized the company's underwriting discipline, noting that Everest's loss reflects careful client selection.
  • Operating income for 2024 reached $1.3 billion, with a 9% return on equity despite $1.7 billion in reserve strengthening, predominantly in U.S. casualty lines. Williamson described the results as demonstrating the business's resilience, supported by strong income streams from reinsurance and investments.
  • Reinsurance premium growth of 12.6% during Q4 was driven by property lines and selective specialty expansion, offset by a 7% reduction in U.S. casualty treaty business. Williamson stated that the company walked away from $750 million in North American casualty quota share business since January 1, 2024.
  • The insurance segment saw a casualty premium reduction of 23%, with remediation efforts targeting underperforming accounts. Key wins included multiline and large deductible casualty programs for sophisticated clients.
  • CFO Mark Kociancic reported gross written premiums of $4.7 billion, representing 7.2% growth. The combined ratio was 135.5%, impacted by 37.6 points of prior-year reserve development.

Outlook

  • Williamson noted that Everest's strategic focus would remain on underwriting discipline, particularly in casualty lines where loss cost trends remain elevated. The company is not entering new markets in 2025 but plans to scale operations in its existing 12 international markets.
  • Reinsurance pricing is expected to stabilize or improve following recent catastrophic events, particularly in property catastrophe and European markets. Williamson expects the California wildfires to reinforce pricing discipline in property reinsurance.
  • CFO Kociancic reaffirmed the company's mid-teens total shareholder return target over the cycle, emphasizing capital strength and the potential for share repurchases.

Financial Results

  • The combined ratio for Q4 reached 135.5%, reflecting $1.5 billion of prior-year unfavorable reserve development. Current accident year losses contributed $229 million, driven by Hurricane Milton.
  • Reinsurance achieved a combined ratio of 90.4%, with property cat excess of loss growing 26.2% for the year. Attritional combined ratio improved by 140 basis points to 83.7%, excluding profit commissions.
  • Insurance gross written premiums declined 1.6%, reflecting casualty remediation offset by 30% growth in property and specialty lines. The attritional loss ratio for insurance increased to 84%, reflecting current accident year strengthening.
  • Net investment income increased to $473 million during Q4, driven by higher assets under management and book yield stability at 4.7%.

Q&A

  • Gregory Peters, Raymond James: Asked about managing volatility given the shift to international property business. Williamson emphasized disciplined capital deployment and reinsurance strategies to manage per-risk volatility.
  • Meyer Shields, Keefe Bruyette & Woods: Inquired about loss ratio progress in the insurance segment. Williamson pointed to prudent reserve actions and improving portfolio mix as tailwinds.
  • Alex Scott, Barclays: Asked about the impact of California wildfires on pricing. Williamson expects this event to reinforce pricing discipline globally, particularly in property catastrophe.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed moderate concern over reserve strengthening and loss cost trends in U.S. casualty lines but recognized the company's proactive approach.
  • Management maintained a confident tone, particularly in highlighting underwriting discipline and resilience in navigating market conditions. Williamson frequently emphasized strategic actions to improve profitability.
  • Compared to Q3, analysts' tone was slightly more pressing, focusing on reserve adequacy and future casualty trends. Management showed consistent confidence but was more cautious in addressing potential risks in U.S. casualty lines.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language shifted to emphasize discipline in casualty underwriting and a narrower focus on international market scaling.
  • Reserve strengthening in Q4 was significantly higher than in Q3, reflecting heightened prudence in U.S. casualty lines.
  • Analysts' focus moved from broad operational performance in Q3 to reserve adequacy and casualty remediation in Q4.
  • Management tone remained firm, but there was a more defensive posture regarding reserve adjustments.

Risks and Concerns

  • Elevated loss cost inflation in U.S. casualty lines remains a key challenge, with assumed trends exceeding 12% in general liability, auto liability, and umbrella lines.
  • Analysts raised concerns about reserve adequacy and the potential for further strengthening in casualty lines.
  • Management noted strategic exits from underperforming accounts and emphasized continued focus on rate adequacy and portfolio mix improvement.

Final Takeaway

Everest Group's Q4 2024 results underscore its focus on underwriting discipline and portfolio remediation, particularly in U.S. casualty lines. While reserve strengthening impacted the quarter, the company demonstrated resilience through growth in reinsurance and specialty lines. Management remains optimistic about achieving mid-teens shareholder returns, supported by strong capital positioning, targeted growth in international markets, and anticipated stabilization in property reinsurance pricing. Investors should monitor ongoing reserve trends and the impact of casualty remediation efforts on profitability.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript
